REMARKS: Original definition is a=20923713 and b=20853810 feet of 1796.   For the 1936 retriangulation OSGB defines the relationship of feet of 1796 to the International metre through log(1.48401603) exactly [=0.3048007491...]. 1/f is given to 7 decimal places.
OSGB Airy 1830 figure rescaled by 1.000035 to best fit the primary triangulation of Ireland.

INFORMATION_SOURCE: \Australian Map Grid Technical Manual\"; National Mapping Council of Australia Special Publication #7; 1972"
REMARKS: Based on the GRS 1967 figure but with 1/f taken to 2 decimal places exactly.

INFORMATION_SOURCE: US Army Map Service Technical Manual; 1943.
REMARKS: Original Bessel definition is a=3272077.14 and b=3261139.33 toise. This used a weighted mean of values from several authors but did not account for differences in the length of the various toise: the \Bessel toise\" is therefore of uncertain length."
Used in Norway and also in Sweden with a 1mm increase in semi-major axis.
a = 6377397.155 German legal metres. This is the same value as the Bessel 1841 figure (code 7004) but in different units.  Used in Namibia.

INFORMATION_SOURCE: \Ellipsoidisch Parameter der Erdfigur (1800-1950)\" by Georg Strasser."
REMARKS: Clarke's 1858/II solution. Derived parameters: a = 6378293.645m using his 1865 ratio of 0.304797265 feet per metre; 1/f = 294.26068…  In historic usage in Australia 1/f taken to two decimal places (294.26 exactly); elsewhere a and b used to derive 1/f.

INFORMATION_SOURCE: US Army Map Service Technical Manual No. 7; 1943.
REMARKS: Original definition a=20926062 and b=20855121 (British) feet. Uses Clarke's 1865 inch-metre ratio of 39.370432 to obtain metres. (Metric value then converted to US survey feet for use in the United States using 39.37 exactly giving a=20925832.16 ft US).
Used for Michigan NAD27 State Plane zones.  Radius = ellipsoid radius + 800 feet; this approximates the average elevation of the state.   Derived parameter: 1/f = 294.97870
Adopts Clarke's values for a and b.  Uses Benoit's 1895 ratio of 0.9143992 metres per yard to convert to metres.
Adopts Clarke's values for a and b using his 1865 ratio of 39.370432 inches per metre to convert axes to metres.
Adopts Clarke's values for a and 1/f.  Adopts his 1865 ratio of 39.370432 inches per metre to convert semi-major axis to metres. Also known as Clarke Modified 1880.
Adopts Clarke's value for a with derived 1/f.  Uses his 1865 ratio of 39.370432 inch per metre to convert semi-major axis to metres.
Used in Old French Triangulation (ATF).   Uses Clarke's 1865 inch-metre ratio of 39.370432 to convert axes to metres.

Used for the 1937 readjustment of Indian triangulation.  Clarke's 1865 Indian-British foot ratio (0.99999566) and Benoit's 1898 British inch-metre ratio (39.370113) rounded as 0.30479841 exactly and applied to Everest's 1830 definition taken as a and 1/f
Adopted 1967 for use in East Malaysia.  Applies Sears 1922 inch-metre ratio of 39.370147 to Everest 1830 original definition of a and 1/f but with a taken to be in British rather than Indian feet.
Adopted 1967 for use in West Malaysia.  Applies Benoit 1898 inch-metre ratio of 39.370113 to Everest 1830 original definition of a and 1/f but with a taken to be in British rather than Indian feet.

INFORMATION_SOURCE: \Geodetic Reference System 1980\" by H. Moritz; Bulletin Geodesique"
REMARKS: Adopted by IUGG 1979 Canberra.  Inverse flattening is derived from geocentric gravitational constant GM = 3986005e8 m*m*m/s/s; dynamic form factor J2 = 108263e8 and Earth's angular velocity = 7292115e-11 rad/s.

INFORMATION_SOURCE: \Ellipsoidisch Parameter der Erdfigur (1800-1950)\" by Georg Strasser"
REMARKS: Helmert 1906/III solution.
Based on the GRS 1967 figure but with 1/f taken to 3 decimal places exactly.
Adopted by IUGG 1924 in Madrid. Based on Hayford 1909/1910 figures.
Used by Transit Precise Ephemeris between October 1971 and January 1987.
Rescaling of Delambre 1810 figure (a=6376985 m) to make meridional arc from equator to pole equal to 10000000 metres exactly. (Ref: Strasser).

INFORMATION_SOURCE: \Geodesia y Cartografia Matematica\" by Fernando Martin Asin; ISBN 84-398-0248-X."
REMARKS: Original definition of semi-major axis given as 3272539 toise.  In \Ellipsoidisch Parameter der Erdfigur (1800-1950)\"
CHANGE_ID: Strasser suggests a conversion factor of 1.94903631 which gives a=6378297.337 metres."

REMARKS: Inverse flattening derived from four defining parameters (semi-major axis; C20 = -484.16685*10e-6; earth's angular velocity w = 7292115e11 rad/sec; gravitational constant GM = 3986005e8 m*m*m/s/s).
Used for  GEM 10C Gravity Potential Model.
Used for OSU86 gravity potential (geoidal) model.
Used for OSU91 gravity potential (geoidal) model.

INFORMATION_SOURCE: \Ellipsoidisch Parameter der Erdfigur (1800-1950)\" by Georg Strasser."
REMARKS: Clarke gave a and b and also 1/f=293.465 (to 3 decimal places).  1/f derived from a and b = 293.4663077…
Authalic sphere.  1/f is infinite.

INFORMATION_SOURCE: \Geodetic Reference System 1967\"; International Association of Geodesy special publication number 3; August 1971."
REMARKS: Adopted by IUGG 1967 Lucerne.  Inverse flattening given is derived from geocentric gravitational constant (GM)= 398603e9 m*m*m/s/s; dynamic form factor (J2) = 0.0010827 and Earth's angular velocity w = 7.2921151467e-5 rad/s.

INFORMATION_SOURCE: New Brunswick Geographic Information Corporation land and water information standards manual
\Ellipsoidisch Parameter der Erdfigur (1800-1950)\" by Georg Strasser"
REMARKS: Everest gave a and b to 2 decimal places and also 1/f=300.8017 (to 4 decimal places).

Used by Pakistan since metrication.  Clarke's 1865 Indian foot-British foot ratio (0.99999566) and his 1865 British inch-metre ratio (39.369971) rounded with slight error as 1 Ind ft = 0.3047995m exactly and applied to Everest's 1830 definition of a & b.

Used by India since metrication.  Clarke's 1865 Indian foot-British foot ratio (0.99999566) and his 1865 British inch-metre ratio (39.369971) rounded as 1 Ind ft = 0.3047995m exactly applied to Everest's 1830 original definition taken as a and b.
